OtherHalfBrewing.name: Other Half Brewing

reviews.text: The scene of a Saturday morning can release is truly something to behold. Love these fellas. And considering their Gowanus Canal water supply, their product is impossibly delicious ðŸ˜‰

I love this place. The staff is friendly, the beer is ridiculous, and the lines are never long for releases. The brewery is dog friendly and sells very cool merchandise. In addition, they have a local sandwich shop that posts up for their releases! You really can't beat the experience :)
Great little brewery, with an outdoor space. Very good beers, especially if you are an IPA fan. If you want to visit for a release, come early so you can get them before they sell out!
Great ipas. A lot of rotation with can releases every other Saturday. The tap room is on the small side, but nice - you're probably there for the beer anyways. Would recommend.

Fun, small place that serves some decent beer. Heavy on the IPA side, but of those they're awesome. Has a lot of collaboration beers and is active in the local beer scene. If you want to fill a growler make sure it's wide mouth or they can't fill it because of their system.

Quarters are tight, like, super-tight.

Beers are hoppy, like, super-hoppy.

If words like: Amarillo, Citra, Simcoe, and Mosaic hold meaning to you...you've...

beers.beerDescription: An imperial IPA brewed with Golden Promise malt and lots of Australian Galaxy hops.
A huge, but dry, triple IPA packed with Motueka, Amarillo, Citra and Mosaic.
A west coast style IPA packed with Cascade, Centennial, Chinook and Simcoe.
Citra, Amarillo & Ahtanium hops
Session ipa with Apollo, Azacca, Citra, Jaaryco & Mosaic
Single Hop Imperial IPA
Single hop Double IPA. All mosaic all the time.
Imperial IPA brewed with Citra, Mosaic & El Dorado hops.
Trillium collab, hopped with Motueka, Wai-Iti, Galaxy, Topaz, Citra, and Citra Lupulin Powder. Oo ya babby!!!!
Big, smooth and malty. Hopped with UK Fuggles and East Kent Goldings
El Dorado, Simcoe, Galaxy hopped session pale ale

OtherHalfBrewing.breweryDescription: Other Half Brewing Company was founded in 2014 by Samuel Richardson and Matt Monahan. We brew craft beers for draft consumption, bottles, and cans in limited release. We believe local breweries play an important role in their communities which is why, despite the challenges of running a brewery in NYC, we couldnâ€™t choose anywhere but Brooklyn as our home. The brewery is located on the edge of Carroll Gardens, only two blocks from the subway. Our tap room is open to the public and we also offer tours of our brewery (by appointment).

SinglecutBeersmiths.name: Singlecut Beersmiths

reviews.text: great brewery. very comfortable place where u can spread out a bit and enjoy delicious beers. very friendly and knowledgeable staff as well. get off at astoria ditmars subway stop and grab a $5 cab. easy.

Great low-key and fun location. Usually friendly service and pretty good beer. They've improved a lot since they first opened. 

They sometimes have live music and other events. There are some tasty snacks you can get here as well such as pretzels and bratwurst. 

They offer brewery tours on weekends and you can get growlers or crowlers to go here. Great prices all around.
I really like this place. Really chill. Good prices. Often change their beer selections.
Awesome beer selection, however location isn't that great. Plenty of parking around though.
Great beers.  Great guys with some awesome patience explaining what beer is what and the history of the said beers.  Will Definitely go again on my next trip to the City.
Great local beer for a great price. The seating area is very roomy and there is a selection of borad games to choose from as well. The best part is the $2-3...

beers.beerDescription: When your tastebuds beg for a pounding this IIPA sneaks up with smoothness, and then: Bam! Citrus uppercut! Biff! Dank bitterness! Wham! A piney bite! Ooof! Floral, dank pine and citrus aromas! Kablam! 8.6% ABV! Thank you sir, may I have another!?!
Hopheads rejoice! Want more than just one highly-hopped pint, but don't want the high ABV? Behold! A sessionable IPA with all the lupulin crunch you demand.

Crank the hops to the point right before tastebuds bleed with an original (and hard to get) blend. At 88 IBUs, "Half Stack" is a relative term - As we like to say, "If it's too hoppy, you're too old!"
Our ode the incredible hops coming out of Australia. Big pineapple juicy fruit with a dry finish and pretty aggressive bittering. I'm TNT, dy-no-mite.
Dank resin galore with a heaping of sharp citrus for good measure.
Created from our brewmaster's recipe honed to perfection with an entirely original combination of NZ and PNW hops totaling 110 IBU's.

beers.beerName: Is This the Real Life? IPA
beers.beerDescription: Hopped with Kohatu and then dry hopped with four different PNW hops, three times
Hey y'all! 1) Let's grow a big, bushy beard 2) Let's get [insert multiple number] piercings 3) Sleeves 4) Drink an ale that's got that PNW hop and malt attitude 5) And let's color our hair mahogany
AUGUST IN NYC. It's hot baby, we needed to do something - so a sour lager infused with hibiscus (and black currants but who's counting) seemed like something that would help beat the heat.
We've got a fever. And there is only one cure: a lusciously creamy, slightly sweet Stout that sits atop a chocolate and roast malt base that will rock all night long.

19-33 is an important number for us. Both our address and the year the US repealed prohibition, 19-33 Pilsner is our ode with great Pilsners of yesteryear and some intense modern hop aroma. Dry, crisp, and incredibly labor intensive. Hope you enoy.
Some Cat from Japan asked us to make and IPA that was juicy, and nothing else. So we packed up a pack horse and made it happen. Keep your electric eye on this one.

beers.beerName: Heavy Boots of Lead Imperial Stout
beers.beerDescription: Super complex richness of mega-chocolate, roast, coffee, and vanilla.

Chill quickly. Cell phone: off. Laptop: closed. Shoes: off. Feet: up. Sippin' a pint of this uniquely hued and flavored lager (with subtle spices that are a proprietary blend), it's nice to know that every day also has its night.

SinglecutBeersmiths.breweryDescription:
To all demanding a steadfast meticulousness towards everything that can fit into a pint glass - Welcome. 

To all that support and help promote the growth of our grass-roots celebrated beers, thank you.

reviews.text: Bronx Brewery hasnâ€™t yet gained the fame and crowds of Brooklyn Brewing, but it seems poised to be the next breakout brewery. The setting is good for hanging out most of the day and it helps that the beer is pretty good. They do not serve food so bring something and make a picnic. They have about a dozen brews on tap of various styles and strength. The flagship Banner Ale and the Octoberfest were two of my favorites. They are even dog friendly at the outside section which is awesome. The outside is pretty big with a bunch of picnic tables while inside only has seating for a few folks. The only odd part is the layout where you have to walk through the brewery to get to the outside which can be a bit of a pain with a dog and stroller (if so inclined). Itâ€™s a good place to bring some food and hang out for the whole day while sampling their full range. It does get a bit crowded on weekend evenings these days.
Nice selection I  a tiny space. Snacks offered,  no hot food. Lots of IPA selections. No select parking lot for the space. Fun spot.
I went for a tour and tasting.  Well mostly for the tasting.  It was different to see different people in an area of the Bronx that was not so nice a short time ago.   The bartender was great.

Finally made it to this brewery, I have had a lot of Bronx Brewery American Pale Ales at different event and bars around New York City. It is great to see this destination brewery with my own eyes. Now, this area is an industrial location in the South Bronx.  Driving would be the best way to get here but our group of three decided to take the subway which is very doable with a ten minute walk from the 6 Train stop.

As you approach and enter this large industrial facility, there is tasting room to the left and straight ahead to go into the brewery. If you go through the brewery area, there is a large outdoor space. It's December now so it is definitely off-season for this outdoor location but I was told by the Brooklyn Brewery staff and tour guide, Kate that it is a great space on a summer weekend. They are food trucks and live music. I definitely need to come back and check it out.

They offer free tours of the brewery on the weekend. It was a quiet Sunday afternoon so we had a private tour because we were the only new arrivals at tour time. Kate explained very succinctly and efficiently the brewing process and more about Bronx Brewery. Bronx Brewery stated in 2011 but it only opened this brewery location in 2014 after a few years of renovation woes, thanks Hurricane Sandy.

If you check-in with Yelp, you get $1 off a pint after your tasting. We took advantage of this discount which was much appreciated. We decided to eat before we arrived but there is a good selection of small appetizer types of food such as prosciutto ($10), pretzels ($6) and toketti ($6). The toketti are Sardinian style flatbread chip-type munchies.

For the beer, we tried plenty of brews. We ended up with three different pints. The Rye Pale Ale was our first selection a crisp, golden-orange pale ale with rye and piney hops.  The other two selections were the seasonal brews, Winter and Bogsmash. The Winter Pale Ale is an amber colored pale ale brewed with cinnamon, molasses, cloves and ginger that has a spiced the flavor.  The Bogsmash Pale Ale is a fall brew with cranberries with a subtle tart aftertaste.

A few of my friends have personally recommended this location so I am happy to have made it to this location.

The Bronx Brewery is a great place to hang out with friends, drink a mellow local brew, and grab a bite to eat at the food truck in the back.  The summer ale is very delicious and just-right for the hot summer.  Once you get a beer, head to the outdoor seating area and listen to the live music on weekends.  Good for meeting friends and small groups.
My company had a work event here and it was tons of fun. They had tons of cans in ice tubs laying around. They had their two backyard taps open with beers I...

beers.beerDescription: This deep amber American-style pale ale is brewed with 5 different barley malts, generous additions of Cascade and Centennial hops, and a unique strain of yeast. It is dry-hopped, unfiltered, and unpasteurized.

Malted and flaked rye make up nearly a quarter of the grain bill for this Rye Pale Ale, offering it a unique and intense spicy rye flavor and golden-orange hue.  Chinook and Crystal hops lend a gentle bitterness and spicy, piney and herbal character and aroma to this rich, bold rye beer.

This balanced and refreshing pale ale is perfect for summer days in the city.  Brewed with British and American 2-row malts, a unique experimental hop variety and dried lemon peel, it offers a subtle and crisp citrus note.  It is dry-hopped, unfiltered and unpasteurized.

Loads of tropical fruit â€“ guava, passion fruit and ripe mango â€“ on the nose, a clean, light body, leading to a refreshingly tart, red wheat malt finish establish this easy-drinking yet wonderfully hoppy 5.0% ABV session IPA.

Two strains of Trappist yeast, one Belgian ale yeast, and Belgian candi sugar highlight this remarkably intricate, fruity, spicy, and earthy straw-colored Belgian Pale Ale. Belgian Pilsner and Biscuit malts from Beloeil and German Vienna malts from Bamberg provide a clean backdrop for the spicy and lightly herbal Sterling hops. A votre santÃ© from the Bronx.

This Black Pale Ale offers a smooth and complex contrast of dark chocolate and roasted malt flavors with bright and tropical guava, mango and pear hop flavors and aromas.  Three different American malts stand up to generous amounts of West Coast El Dorado and Citra hops in an unfiltered and unpasteurized ale.  Embrace the darkness of the winter with this hoppy black ale.

If you are looking for a beer to satisfy your New Year's resolution, make no mistake -- this isn't it. This brew brings hop aromas & bitterness in a big way -- a variety of hops create a spectrum of aromas ranging from citrus, pine, musky, tropical fruit to lemon grass. With a 7.6% ABV and a heavy hop guarantee this is the ideal beer for those who go No Resolutions. Cheers!

Our banner beer for those who make stuff happen.

Bronx Banner is a Kolsch-inspired ale that is brewed using Belgian pilsner, American wheat malts & classic Bavarian hops.  Itâ€™s brilliantly clear-filtered, soft and perfectly balanced.

Fresh juice pressed from New York State apples makes up a quarter of the fermentables of this crisp and easy-drinking Autumn Pale Ale, lending it a slightly acidic, fruity and tannic finish.  Northern Brewer hops from the west coast are added to the kettle and conditioning tank, contributing a woody and subtle mint character.
An amber colored pale ale brewed with cinnamon, molasses, cloves & ginger that delivers a delightful winter spiced flavor.

beers.beerName: Bronx Spring Pale Ale with Tea
beers.beerDescription: A blend of black and chamomile teas brewed to perfect balance with 2 row barley malts and refreshing lemongrass and pine hop bitterness.

A fall seasonal brewed with cranberries giving this pale ale a subtle tart finish.

Cranberries can only grow in a few parts of the world and lucky for us, NY State happens to be one of them.  We used cranberries from a few of NY's best bogs to add a subtle tartness to this seasonal pale ale.  The hops we use provide woody aromas & bitterness and the malt's sweetness keeps the acidity of the berries in check.  We feel the Bog Smash is the perfect complement for the crisp outdoor weather we love to enjoy in the fall.  Plus, it's super fun to yell "Bog Smash", so hope you enjoy!

Big floral and tropical aromas set up this delightfully balanced white IPA.

Soft yet slightly tart wheat and lightly toasted malts are complemented by the gentle bitterness of the hops.  Our brewers use late hop additions and dry hopping in the brewing process to give this IPA its big hop nose without an overwhelmingly bitter taste.  This brew is love at first smell.  Cheers!

A rich, full bodied stout that delivers a dark roasted and chocolate taste that would make any coffee drinker smile.

Heaps of small-batch roasted Ethiopian coffee from Uptown Coffee Roasters (our next door neighbor) lead the charge in this rich, creamy coffee milk stout.  The milk sugar we add gives it plenty of sweetness but itâ€™s balanced by floral, earthy and mildly bitter Willamette hops so you wonâ€™t have too much sugar in your coffee.  If youâ€™re looking for something sweet and chocolatey to warm you up on a cold NYC winter night look no further.

A spicy Rye IPA thatâ€™s balanced with a generous amount of West Coast hops, giving this brew a strong, pleasant bitterness and raising it to Imperial status with an 8.1% ABV. Our devotion to our Rye Ale runs deep.  After all, it was the second beer we ever brewed.  But we couldnâ€™t resist the temptation to make a bigger, more badass version and this spicy Rye IPA delivers.  With heavy citrus aromas on thenose and a crisp, dry, warm finish on the mouth, itâ€™s a complex, yet finely balanced big hoppy beer with an 8.1% ABV that we canâ€™t get enough of.  Looks like we committed some infidelity with our Rye Fidelity.

reviews.text: Decent Beers. Friendly Staff. Nice Atmosphere (Very Hipster). The Meat Hook provides the food, super expensive.  They claim an amazing burger (They lie). They failed to cook burger Med-Rare ($13 for 1/3 lb cheese burger). Overall very disappointed!!!

The beer here is very good. I didn't have the food, but it smells amazing and everyone is eating something ,  so it must be good. Kinda feels like your in a restaurant and not a brewery. Plus, the Outdoor area is nice too.

Excellent selection of Three's made beer, as well as cans and bottles from other sought after Brooklyn breweries. Outdoor patio is a nice plus, although on a 65 degree night they needed to turn off the heat lamps. Prices are about average, and the service was good but not great.

Excellent experience. Persuaded my girlfriend to pop in for a final drink before our flight back to the UK and it ended up being 3 and food. Lovely guys behind the bar, exciting food, music that will suit most tastes, and an excellent choice of beers: 20 of their own, 8 guests. Highly recommended to make any effort to get here.

Beautiful place if you ask a photographer.

Some cool beers.

Great burger a little overpriced, awesome place though.
There's a whole lot more beer to be had in Brooklyn beyond that burrow-named brewery. For starters, there's this awesome little/big spot filled with stellar...

beers.beerDescription: Tropical, Assertive, Lush, Oily, Candied Tangerines.
Mango, Southern Tea, Dank, Lychee, Snowpine.
Pineapple, Green Papaya, Pine Candy, Mild Bitterness, Dry Finish.
Floral, Fruity, Citrus Pith, Dry.
Clean, Sweet Hay, Herbal Hops, Verdant.
Jackfruit, Pine Resin, Melon Rind, Cucumber, Fruit Punch.
Honeydew, White Grape, Pillowy, Vinous, Restrained Citrus. Brett Fermented Pale Ale.
Lemon Flesh, Cracked Wheat, Fresh, Soft.
Rose Petals, Ripe Pear, Musk, White Pepper.
Mango, Fresh Cut Grass, Orange Marmalade, Biscuit, Bitter Grapefruit.
Tangerine, Spring Pine, White Peach, Nuanced.

beers.beerName: Everything Was Forever, Until It Was No More
beers.beerDescription: Bittersweet Chocolate, Roasted Malt, Dark Fruit, Warming, Rich.
Tropical, Juicy Pine, Citrus, Moderate Bitterness
Pineapple, Spruce Tips, Pungent, Coaxing.
Juicy, Grapefruit, Fruit Loops, Moderate Bitterness, Dry. IPA w/ Oats.

LICBeerProject.name: LIC Beer Project

reviews.text: Cool little place. Clean, nice layout for warmer weather (open garage style). Would be great if they had some bar snacks to pair with their beers.
Really like this spot. Great beers and a nice wide-open feel to the brewery makes it a perfect location for drinks with the crew. I think Higher Burnin' is one of the best beers I've ever had.
We enjoyed sampling the different beers here, especially the sour. Nice environment although its not overly large, staff was friendly and helpful.
Friendly staff, great rotating selection of fabulous Belgian style beers and the most relaxed atmosphere for a brewery in the area.
The beer ranges from decent to fantastic. The service, at its best, is only a notch above ambivalent. I will not return; however, I will happily order their beer at other venues.
I've been coming to LIC Beer Project sporadically for over a year now because it's conveniently located right near my gym (Brooklyn Boulders Queensbridge)...

beers.beerDescription: A Belgian inspired golden ale brewed with our house saison yeast and generously hopped with a blend of aromatic noble hops. The final result is softly contoured pale golden ale with an aroma rife with floral, spice and earth. The finish is crisp and dry.

Pile of Crowns is a medium bodied Imperial IPA, which employs a blend of hops including Citra, Mosaic, and Nugget. This exceedingly aromatic ale entices with peach, mango, and papaya. It finishes smooth and dry with accents of orange and berries.
Our newest India Pale Ale brewed with late additions of Belma, Azacca, and Amarillo resulting in a medium bodied IPA with juicy fruit, strawberry, earthy and piney notes finishing resinous and dry.
Hoppy Brett Ale

Pine, citrus, dank, resin, juicy, earthy, soft, hazy, citrus, melon, stone fruit, pith, passionfruit, lychee, zest, grapefruit, pungent, floral, cream, peach, mango, pineapple, guava, papaya, and fluffy.

Brewed in collaboration with Root + Branch Brewing. Brewed with American malted barley, wheat malt and flaked oats. Hopped with a blend of
American citrus forward hops. Fermented with our house ale yeast strain.
Double dry hopped. Features prominent notes of grapefruit and candied orange
with undertones of stone fruit and sticky pine. 42 IBU / 5.5% ABV
Rye Saison
A kolsch-inspired ale named after LICBP's neighborhood. Golden in color with a mild hoppy backbone.

This decidedly American take on a Belgian saison is expressing ripe aromatics that blur the line between hops and yeast. A well hopped saison with grassy floral notes, hints of bubblegum, and bready malt. Finishes light body with a noticeable bitterness.

A French country ale brewed with our house saison yeast. Appearance is a deep leathery copper with a pillowy beige head. Big spice and bready malt character on the palate from the generous additions of Munich malt, Special B, and orange peel. Lagered cold, this beer finishes clean and dry with a firm earthy bitterness.

LICBeerProject.breweryDescription: LIC Beer Project is a collaborative journey of insight, experience, travel, education, and the goal to achieve a beer we have yet to discover. Here at LIC Beer Project we will assert integrity of purpose and imaginative vision against the slaves of the ordinary. Join the odysseyâ€¦â€¦

reviews.text: If it's your first time, try one of the flights! Good beer. Fun atmosphere. Nice staff.

Pretty great beer, nice to have in a neighborhood like this!  The taproom is a bit smaller than I expected, so it may be a bit difficult to get a seat in the busier times, but it's a great brewery to visit.

Local brewery. The Rockaway Brewing Company donates their used grain bags to the non-profit Surfrider Foundation NYC Chapter who use those bags for their beach cleanups. The RBC is a very community minded company. Check them out.
Awesome welcoming tap room with friendly staff. Great selection of beer for all.

I love this kind of places. Simple, not crowded, laid back. Just serves beer, no food other than a few snacks. But they let you bring your own food. Beers are very good, and let you taste them so you can find the best that suits you very easily. Hope to visit them multiple times this summer

If you're only going to visit one of LIC's four (soon to be 5) breweries, THIS is the one you want to check out...

There's always a diverse selection of...

beers.beerDescription: An India Pale Ale amber in color with a sturdy malt backbone and a hoppy punch accompanied by a fruity aroma. Closer to an English style IPA, pre west coast American hop craze.
All New York State ingredients, hoppy instead of metallic.
A well rounded red ale with a grapefruit hop presence.

TransmitterBrewing.name: Transmitter Brewing

reviews.text: Cool brewery. Off the beaten path. Only bottles their beer which makes it difficult to enjoy just a selection for a true tasting

If you love beer, you need to go here. 

Transmitter brews truly delicious beers (such as my favorite stout and one of the best triples I've ever had). Everything is bomber style, but the beers aren't too high gravity. Very rich, complex, nuanced flavors. Wide variety of brew types, all great. Make sure you pour with a little head, because every beer has a delicious one. But, those are just their beers, which you can get in a few places. 

The tasting session at the brewery itself is amazing. You're literally tucked away in a corner of the brewery at small makeshift tables. The kegs and brew instruments are right there. So it smells like beer being made and you can watch them close out their day and see how they brew. They're more than willing to talk about the brews and they all have a great passion for brewing. It ends up being an amazing experience for a beer lover. Can't recommend enough. 

Love the brew dog too!

Good albeit VERY small tasting room. They do bottle conditioned beers so they'll have a few open for free tasting. If you like one then you can buy a bottle and drink in the tasting room. Everyone there is really nice and friendly and the prices are good too, especially given everything is bottled.
Great spot off the beaten path to enjoy a sour. No taps but plenty of well-executed and bottle conditioned farmhouse ales ready to taste. It's like a Belgium picnic between fermenters.
Cosy little brew bar, with a tasty range of sours & wilds ðŸ‘ŒðŸ»

If you're a farmhouse/saison fan, Transmitter Brewing is your spot!

The brewery itself is quite small with a few benches, but once you you walk in, you get...

beers.beerDescription: Tart Golden Ale
Notes of pepper, stone fruits. Pilsner & White Wheat malt with French Saison Yeast earthy dry beer. Effervescent. Clean yeast profile & subtle dry hopping. Delicious as weather warms.
Saison Brewed with toasted rice and New School German hops. Notes of pear and melon witha light body and lightly spicy undertone.

beers.beerName: W3 Imperial Hibiscus Wit With Orange And Coriander

beers.beerDescription: Rye, Wheat and Pilsner Malt with grapefruit peel, black pepper and coriander

A hoppy Farmhouse with brett brewed by Beer Culture at Transmitter Brewing. The base malt is Maris Otter with Vienna and Munich added for color and toasted maltiness. Legacy, Nuggetzilla and Cascade hops added toward the end for some added fruitiness. A single strain of brett is used for fruity, earthy and dry finish.
Three strains of Brett in primary fermentation.
Rye adds a spicy note to this clean effervescent saison that uses yeast cultured from a nectarine skin.
Dry American farmhouse ale with a peach/citrus nose and grapefruit notes.

TransmitterBrewing.breweryDescription: Micro Brewery located in LIC, Queens with a focus on Saison and Farmhouse ales.

StrongRopeBrewery.name: Strong Rope Brewery

reviews.text: Tiny brewery.  Decent beer.  Not a lot of seating.  No Food, (yet?).

Strong Rope is your best friend's basement but 100 times better. It's a brewery that doubles as a cozy bar with some great tasting beer. They have sampler beers in 3oz, a 10oz size as well as a pint at 16oz. I really love the low-key vibe. You can stay as long as you want. Bring a bunch of people to relax and have good conversation.
Great microbrewery. Beers are well priced and it's got a nice calm atmosphere (I went there on a Saturday around 3). Good space.
Nice spot, they make some very nice beers but they don't do the hop bombs that other places do

This is a new and welcome addition to the neighborhood. I loved each beer I tried. It's a cool relaxed vibe and the bartenders are very helpful and friendly. They know all the ins and outs of their process and can give good recommendations. Ample room for seating and the crowd is friendly.
Freshest single best brew bar in Brooklyn right now. 3's has other brewery's on tap.. not here.. they make their ipas, strawberry beer and brown stouts...

beers.beerDescription: Very smooth.
Seasonal saison brewed with lavender and blueberries
Floral tropical Pepper
NY craft malt: Munich; Valley Malt; Chocolate Rye. Chocolate, roasted barley, roasted oats; Briess malting: Chocolate, dark chocolate, caramel 120; Hops: Whipple Bros: Willamette
"Petite Barleywine"

StrongRopeBrewery.breweryDescription: Strong Rope Brewery is a brewery and taproom selling handcrafted ales, made in Brooklyn and focusing on using New York state ingredients. The ales will range from reinterpretations of classic styles to seasonal varieties that utilize the best that local farms have to offer.

reviews.text: What can I say? Fantastic beers, place gets super-full and noisy, but you can still talk if you wander away from the bar over to where the brewing tanks are. Simple Pleasures: East IPA, straight from the tap at the brewery - delicious and refreshing. Also the Local 1 Belgian-style Golden Ale (which is almost too easy to drink, considering its whopping 9% alcohol content)

The beer is great. Good staples as choices and the quality and freshness was what you'd expect. Staff was friendly and quick. 

The big downside is the setup of this place: you wait in a line to get in, then wait in a line to get tokens, then wait in a line to exchange those tokens for beer. Could they have a more convoluted process? The tables and seating might as well not exist as the place is over-crowded and, as other reviewers note, full of drunk twenty-somethings. 

Bottom line: If you're a grumpy old person - prepare to be unhappy. If you're a drunk twenty-something - prepare to wait in line to get decent beer surrounded by your peers and frowning old(er) people.

We came in on the first warm Saturday of the year, around 4pm, which was way too late. The line was crazy long, and they sold out of tour tickets for the rest of the day, and the line to get tokens was too long and the line to get beer was long and... I don't know. I just didn't love it. 

Pros: Very cool space. 
Cons: It was overcrowded. And $5 for a plastic cup of beer is fine, I guess, but I wish they'd had more sample options (tastings of all the beers for like $20 or something).

We ended up talking our way onto the 4:30 tour by chance, which redeemed this trip - but I wouldn't count on that working again. The tour was pretty simple, the tour guide was cool and funny but it was pretty basic. Not sure I'd come back, honestly, or recommend it to anyone if they're not super into Brooklyn Brewery already.

I don't even like beer; came with some friends... I thought the place was pretty cool, and despite hating every beer I drink, the Yuka (fruit beer) was easily drinkable! Only negative is the seating availability. There's no place to sit; they could easily rearrange the place to maximize seating.

I used to love going to this place in the early 2000s. Now it's not as good. Gets super duper crowded with Millenials who seem to be getting drunk fit the first time. Fresh beer. Usually 4-5 choices. Get pizza delivered here. Don't think you'll get a table for happy hour if you show up after 6:30pm.
Decided to bring some friends and do the brewery tour to start off my birthday bash this year, and while I'm not crazy about Brooklyn's standard beers, I...

beers.beerDescription: Caramel-forward vienna lager with dry-hopped aroma.
Hoppy balanced IPA derived from english and american styles.
Light-bodied refreshing summer pale ale.
Citrusy farmhouse saison featuring the rare sorachi ace hop.
Robust american imperial stout.
Roasty american brown ale.
Big balanced double IPA packed with american and english hops.
American pumpkin ale with a warm aroma, biscuity malt center and crisp finish.
MÃ¤rzen lager with full malty body, bready aroma and light hop bitterness.
Rich hearty scottish-style ale.
Bottle refermented belgian strong golden ale with gently sweet stone fruit flavors and dry finish.
Session saison packed with bright, citrusy hop flavor.
Snappy and refreshing german style pilsner.

Brooklyn Pennant Ale is a honey-colored pale ale with a brisk malt palate and finely balanced hop character. Pennant is a traditional English-style pale ale. Ours is brewed from Scottish Maris Otter malt, which is justly prized for its toasty, biscuity flavor and the round smoothness it imparts to beer. Our house ale yeast brings out an appetizing fruitiness and ferments to a dry finish.

Here in New York City, things are complicated, fast and loud. So sometimes we want a nice beer that's simply tasty and refreshing. Brooklyn American Ale is easygoing, versatile, and dependable. It's a beer you and your friends can hang out with, no matter where you're from. Try it alongside pizza, burgers, spicy foods, sharp cheese, or just another bottle of American Ale.

TheFlagshipBrewingCompany.name: The Flagship Brewing Company

reviews.text: Small disclaimer, I'm not really much of a beer drinker. With that out of the way, what a delight. We have a craft brewery on the Island. Very easy to get to by train. Their beers are nice. I had the sampler. Like I stated, I'm not a beer person so I can't give you expert opinion on them. The space is really great. I haven't been here at peak hours. But in the weekday afternoon it's very chill. Nice place to hang out with friends. Wish there were more places like this around here.

When looking for beer one always needs to go for the freshest possible. That's why a brewery or brewpub is the choice. This is (so far) the only place on The Rock that fits that bill. Try the IPA. My fave.

They have excellent beer, check the calendar for local events. The trivia contests are really fun, and Fleet Week 2016 had a great outdoor music festival by the Staten Island Ferry. Community style seating, you can even order food from other local restaurants. The merchandise is cool, too.

The beer here is pretty good, but the atmosphere is AMAZING.

Big ole stage for live music. And there's a ton of room to feel comfortable and hang out. The guys working the taps are great and friendly and happy to chat with you about beer.

I hope that they start getting a little more daring with their brews at some point, but they are still young, so they definitely have time to evolve!
Awesome beer and super friendly staff. Best brewery in nyc!
In my opinion some of the best beer in the city this place is the best fresh clean amazing tasting beer from the island thank you for making such a quality...

beers.beerDescription: The hop profile of Flagship APA includes an upfront bitterness complemented with citrus and pine-like aromas followed by a small burst of tropical fruit. Malted barley provides a deep auburn color and a sweet, biscuit-like backbone helping the flavor balance nicely with the bitterness from the hops. The mouthfeel is medium bodied with a hoppy and crisp finish.

Flagship American Wit is a refreshing, light bodied wheat beer. Prized hops from Americaâ€™s northwest region give this ale a citrusy flavor blended with the subtle undertones of our hand ground spices. A balancing malt profile contributes a recognizable golden color in addition to a slight haze from the yeast.

Flagship Breweryâ€™s â€œMetropolitan Lagerâ€ is a golden lager that features toasted Vienna and Rye malts. The Rye adds a smooth mouthfeel while floral noble hops are used in abundance for flavor and aroma. This lager is smooth, clean, crisp and exceptionally balanced.

A showcase of some of Flagshipâ€™s favorite hop varieties and executed by using them in abundance. Each hop in IPA lends a unique flavor that when blended produces bursting fruit flavors from citrusy grapefruit to tropical mango in harmony with an ever so slight roast character from the golden malted barley. Designed for full hop flavor experience without overpowering bitterness.

A malty brew that uses Vienna and Munich varieties of malted barley that are complemented with German malted rye and German chocolate rye. Bavarian noble hops balance the beer with a mild bitterness and soft floral aroma. The result is a full-bodied dark copper colored ale with a smooth texture and spicy-like characteristic from the rye malt.

A foundation consisting of American wheat and Golden Promise malts give this beer light sweetness and a slight haze. The all-star of this ale is a hop called â€œSummer.â€ This spawn of the noble hop, Saaz, is subtle and used in abundance contributing slight aromas of hop spice, earthiness, and tropical melon. American ale yeast helps to provide a crispness that is dry but balanced. Deep yellow color and a light body make this summer beer approachable and sessionable.

Flagship Dark Mild is black in color due to a complex malt profile thatâ€™s packed with flavor by using a wide variety of roasted, toasted, and caramel malts. The mildness comes from a soft hop character and lower alcohol content making this light bodied ale a sessionable salute to our fondness for dark beer.

As we approach the inevitable winter, Flagship introduces â€œWee Heavy.â€  Brewed in the style of strong Scottish ales, a longer boil adds â€œcaramelizationâ€ to the brewing process and helps produce a full body and higher alcohol content in addition to malty sweetness. We Americanize this dark brown colored beer by using a copious amount of pacific northwest hops.

The British Mild is a session ale known for soft hop character and lower alcohol content. Flagship VAN DAM is black in color due to a complex malt profile. Using a wide variety of roasted, toasted, and caramel malts, this ale is bursting with dark beer character. The addition of Madagascar Bourbon vanilla blends a pleasant richness to the existing flavors. A medium but mellow body gives VAN DAM enjoyable drinkability during the winter months.

The pairing of Stout with oysters has been enjoyed for centuries and Flagship Oyster Stout combines the two into one delicious apÃ©ritif. Roasted barley united with chocolate rye, midnight wheat, and flaked oats gives this brew dark color and roasty flavor while providing a smooth mouthfeel and rich body. The flavor blends nicely with a mineral brininess from Long Island harvested oysters that are boiled in the brewing process, shell and all. Designed to be enjoyed with oysters raw or cooked, but approachable and encouraged to be enjoyed all occasions.
Dry hopped with Motueka and Galaxy hops
Baltic porter using locally roasted Kona coffee beans

TheFlagshipBrewingCompany.breweryDescription: Unforgettable Beer.... Brewed in the Forgotten Borough.

ChelseaCraftBrewingCompany.name: Chelsea Craft Brewing Company

reviews.text: I came to Chelsea last weekend with my friends and it was our second stop on our own personal brewery crawl. The owners  were extremely welcoming and told us about their history and how they just moved to the Bronx. I've been to a lot of breweries - and this was easily the most personal and best tour I've ever been given. The food is great - especially the beer cheese with the pretzels, and the beer is really tasty and different. I highly recommend it to anyone in NYC looking for a great experience and great beer. ðŸ‘ŒðŸ¼
Nice people great beer what more can I say oh yes a full kitchen with outstanding food come hungry ðŸ˜€ðŸ˜€ðŸ˜€
Beer is delicious and crisp. To get the best of the experience, I'd recommend a few flights of all the beer. Buffalo wings are juicy and tender.
Great craft beer, friendly staff. Definitely coming back!!
Awesome tap room, great food, and very friendly people at CCB
I visited the brewery with a cool social ride during Octoberfest. They are definitely bike friendly. They even had live music and corn hole. They have lots...

beers.beerDescription: The perfect beer for fall. A crisp American wheat ale with butternut squash, lightly spiced with cinnamon, nutmeg, allspice, ginger and a touch of honey.
Dark, sweet, coffee finish. GABF medal winner

beers.beerName: New York State Of Mind Wet Hop
beers.beerDescription: Brewed with fresh Chinook hops grown in the Finger Lakes, this is a tasty seasonal ale not to be missed.
NYC, winter amber

ChelseaCraftBrewingCompany.breweryDescription: The newest brewery to hit The Bronx. Winner of many awards and medals including gold, silver & bronze at the Great American Beer Festival and  FX Matt Memorial Cup for Best Craft Brewery in New York State

BridgeandTunnelBrewery.name: Bridge and Tunnel Brewery

reviews.text: Hidden gem -- but likely not for long. Super laid back and no pretenses. Very friendly. Oh and yeah, their brews are delicious.
great beers and that's all that matters. funky industrial space with friendly people - and a focus on production. come check it out and see real deal micro/craft. these guys are living it.
Great find!  Good beer, people and space to enjoy yourself!

An amazing place to visit for a really good craft beer and friendly conversation with the staff. The brewmaster has a passion for his work, which is evident in care given to the beer and the hospitality show to the patrons. Visiting this bar, with it's open brewery, gave me a deeper sense of appreciation for beer.
Great brews and even better prices! I suggest the Sewer Alligator! The atmosphere leans more toward comfy and relaxed than night life, night out, but it's still a great time no matter what!

3.5 stars...

Bridge and Tunnel Brewery started as a nano brewery in Maspeth a couple miles away a few years ago but has expanded operations and is now a...

beers.beerDescription: Southern English brown ale with a strong malty backbone, and huge hazelnut flavor from real hazelnuts added to the mash.

Coffee cream ale brewed especially for The Queens Kickshaw's 3rd anniversary. The beer name is a reference to a story that Kickshaw co-owner Ben Sandler tells of his experience growing up in Long Island City. When Ben was a kid attending grammar school in Queens, his dad would send him to school with a switchblade in one pocket, and a twenty-dollar bill in the other, and basically leave it up to him to decide whether or not he wanted to throw the twenty bucks down or carve his attackers up like a Thanksgiving turkey.

beers.beerName: Pickin' Up The Change Chipotle Porter
beers.beerDescription: A roasty 6.2% ABV, 40IBU Robust Porter with a Chipotle Pepper bite that combines with the back-end bitterness. A beer dedicated to the 80s NYC Hardcore bands and fans.

beers.beerName: Ol Gilmartin Milk and Oatmeal Stout
beers.beerDescription: Milk stout with an ample amount of flaked oats in the grain bill.
Habanero spiced IPA. First batch exclusive to the Sampler. Ask Rafael about the origins of the name.

beers.beerName: Slaughter House Stampede Black Rye IPA

beers.beerDescription: Vanilla bean, French roast coffee, dark chocolate malts, smooth finish
Session IPA, 5% ABV, 85 IBUs.

In 1642, the first Dutch Colonists came to Queens (present day Maspeth). But within that first year, they got their asses kicked, then booted out (back to Manhattan Island) by the Mespeatches Native American tribe (origins of the name 'Maspeth'). This beer is a recipe using ingredients that those first Dutch colonists would have had access to in 1642. Barley and Cluster hops were available at the time but often in short supply, so to supplement a recipe, colonial brewers used corn, rye, wheat, oats, buckwheat, and honey in their grain bills. To supplement bittering hops if in short supply, spruce tips would be used. All above ingredies are included in this recipe. The rsult is a balanced, sessiony ale - slightly cloudy (from the wheat), slightly earthy and bitter (from the spruce addition) - with a story to ponder... Sort of the 'b' side version of the story of Thanksgiving. 
Call it a colonial pale, old fashioned ale, a gruit, or whatever category you think fits.

beers.beerName: Bound By Chains Double Rye IPA
beers.beerDescription: NY S.M.A.S.H. offering.
Spiced Honey Wheat

BridgeandTunnelBrewery.breweryDescription: Established in Sept 2012 as a self-built nano-brewery operating out of a 150 square foot garage in Maspeth Queens NY. As of Nov. 2015, the brewery is now a micro brewery operating on a self built 10 barrel system at 15-35 Decatur Street, Ridgewood Queens NY.

SixpointBrewery.name: Sixpoint Brewery

reviews.text: I'm a bartender and Resin is one of my go to beers, personally. I work at a high volume music club and the Sixpoint lineup consistently outperforms any other craft beers we have in house. I'd recommend this beer to any casual drinker, beer snob, or business owner looking to expand his craft beer menu.
The staff is awesome. There might be an attached brewpub soon, but not at the moment.

Disappointingly....not a tasting room, not open to the public, no phone number to confirm anything. How can a business not have a phone number?! Was looking forward to trying these beers fresh from the brewery â˜¹ï¸

I had a dish with roasted salmon that was absolutely delicious ! We were exhausted after walking up Broadway at going up the Empire State Building: this place was in a great location to just stop there and eat.
The best beer I've ever had! Jammer!
Sixpoint is hands down one of my favorite breweries.  Just about everything they do is exceptional.  love the Resin IIPA, Probably the best double out there...

beers.beerDescription: "Resin" is named after the sticky ooze that secretes from the lupulin glands of the hop cone.
The original Sixpoint style- hard to define, but perhaps that's why people love it. Part pale ale, part wheat, part cream ale- all Sweet Action.
This is the new version of Bengali (originally named Bengali Tiger)
The original Sehr Crisp from Sixpoint. Brewed with noble hops for indelible sehr crisp flavor.

It may be the calm before the storm, but no one can deny the beer climate is changing. Season(al)s are creeping, traditional styles are melting down, and storm clouds are rolling in. Sounds like itâ€™s time for an updated formulation â€” a different sort of winter warmer for a changing globe. A cloudy, unfiltered, hop-intensified Global Warmer should do the trick. Or, we could kid ourselves and deny the whole thingâ€¦

...Once our eyes were opened to the potential of the hop cone, we couldnâ€™t be stopped. With a laser focus, we magnified the hop factor, and pushed the boundaries of flavor, aroma, and perception itself to create HI-RES. Itâ€™s Mad Science.
If you love Resin, try tasting it straight from the tanks. Thatâ€™s Puff â€“ a hazy, unfiltered pour straight from the tanks, with an extra dose of dry hops... a new blend devised just for Puff.
The unmistakeable flavor of a Bavarian Wheat, but with a clear golden brilliance and a Sixpoint twist. An entirely unique canned offering for the sun-worshipping ale lovers.

Take thou also unto thee wheat, and barley, and beans.. and put them in one vessel. The beans of bygone brewers, united with cacao and coffee, to create a trinity of roasted, rich, and savory flavors.
Made with Rye malt to provide a signature and distinct earthy character. Seasoned and dry-hopped with herbal and citrus hops. Truly Righteous.
The Mad Scientists kept tweakin' that jammer until it rocked just right:  grains, water, & salt make up this flavorful and simple brew.
This undefinable black brew is part black IPA, part American Stout, but 100% Diesel powered. Robust chocolate and roasted flavors, with thick pine hop flavor and aroma.
You started with cream in your coffee, now have coffee in your cream ale. Pour up a bright blonde coffee ale and end your day the way you started it. With a delicious craft brew.

â€¦my ancestors danced around a campfire and drank strange brews. Many Beasts were present. The drums were pounding; the rhythm was jamming. Letâ€™s keep the fire going, and the ritual. Love your Beastâ€¦ its Mad Science.
Sixpoint Cycliquid Designed by the Mad Scientists.  Made with a proprietary blend of five fruit juices and beer.

SixpointBrewery.breweryDescription: Founded 2004 within an 800 square foot garage in Red Hook, Brooklyn NYC.

FinbackBrewery.name: Finback Brewery

reviews.text: Love this place, some of the best beer being made in New York right now. Releases don't eat up your whole day and they generally have cans to pick up if you stop by.

Love the beers they make and that they go out of the comfort zone and make beers with ingredients you never thought would go well together. Facility was clean and open, not crowded when we went and had great service. Highly reccomend especially to hop heads
This place is incredible, they make amazing IPAs that are some of the best I've ever had. It's probably one of my top 3 breweries.

small and extremely high quality craft brewery in an odd little warehouse off the beaten track in queens. stark but comfortable tap room and chill place for a drink (or growler). definitely worth making the detour. make sure to check the hours though because they can vary.

the double session was a delight; was in nyc and tried it at vic's in noho and was mesmerized by the taste and after glow ... very refreshing ... we need this in new england (a RI resident); ship some up to the "package" stores in little rhody and massachusetts ...
anyone that says this place is hard to get to is definitely not from new york, let alone queens; the q55 takes you two blocks away. i've never had any...

beers.beerDescription: A Witbier brewed with Szechuan Peppercorns and ginger. It's a Szechuan Session beer. Pronounced "sesh".
Passion fruit gose sour ale.
Coconut IPA.
To all you funky citizens of the universe, we introduce to you Starchild. Cruising through intergalactic space with your pucker face. Sour ale brewed with grapefruit peel.
Rotating IPA Series. Simcoe, Galaxy, Citra. Check bottom of can for version.
IPA brewed with Magnum, Citra, Waimea, Falconers, Equinox and a brand new experimental hop.
Salt. Citrus. Chili.
#6 Check bottom of can for version: 666
With Coffee
Rotating IPA series. Check bottom of can for release version.

FinbackBrewery.breweryDescription: Brewed with Care in Queens, NYC. Taproom open Wednesday, Thursday & Friday 5-10pm; Saturday 1-10pm; Sunday 1-7pm
